The 1723–1727 Ottoman–Iranian War was a military conflict fought between the Ottoman Empire and the collapsing Safavid Empire of Iran, followed by the Hotak dynasty (after 1725), which had seized Isfahan and dominated Iran. The war ended with a decisive Ottoman victory.
Driven partly by the rapid expansion of Russia along the Caspian coast, the Ottoman Empire entered Iran in 1723. In 1724 the Ottomans concluded a treaty with Russia partitioning Iran’s western and northern regions. After a series of uninterrupted victories, the Ottomans advanced through the Caucasus and western Iran, approaching within 40 km of Qazvin, and secured their territorial gains through the Treaty of Hamadan in 1727.
Background
Following the Treaty of Karlowitz (1699), the Ottoman Empire experienced its first major territorial losses in the West. Although later victories against Russia (1711–1713) and Venice (1715–1718) helped recover some territories, the defeat against the Holy Roman Empire forced the Ottomans to sign the Treaty of Passarowitz (1718), resulting in further losses. Afterward, the empire entered the so-called Tulip Era, a relatively peaceful period lasting until 1730.
Meanwhile, the Safavid Empire, which had ruled Iran since 1502, was in decline. Baluch tribes raided Kerman, the Afghan Hotaks attacked Khorasan, and the Lezgins ravaged Shirvan and Dagestan. The Safavid attempt to impose Shi‘ism on the Afghan population of Kandahar sparked a rebellion led by Mir Wais. After killing the Georgian governor Gurgin Khan in 1709, the Afghans advanced westward, defeating the Safavids at the Battle of Gulnabad (1722) and capturing Isfahan on 23 October 1722. Shah Sultan Husayn abdicated, while his son Tahmasp fled to Qazvin and proclaimed himself Shah.
Russian advance
After ending the Great Northern War in 1721 with the Treaty of Nystad, Russia turned southward. A new treaty with the Ottomans in 1721 secured peace. In 1722 Peter the Great launched an invasion of Iran, occupying Makhachkala, Tarki, Derbent, Rasht (March 1723), and Baku (July 1723).
The Ottomans, concerned by Russia’s rapid advance, debated intervention. Envoys from Sunni-majority northern Shirvan requested Ottoman protection; their petition was accepted in late 1722. Rising tensions subsided only when Russia assured the Ottomans it would not cross south of the Caucasus.
In January 1723, the Ottoman envoy Osman Agha presented demands to Afghan ruler Mahmud but was rejected, prompting the Ottoman decision to invade Iran.
The War
Ottoman entry into Georgia (1723)
Ottoman forces aided Georgian ruler Vakhtang VI, who opposed the Safavid appointee Muhammad Quli Khan. Administratively, Kartli was granted as an ocaklık (hereditary governorship) to Vakhtang’s son Ibrahim. Tbilisi fell to the Ottomans on 23 June.
Capture of Ganja and Somkhiti (1723)
Ottoman armies continued their advance, capturing Ganja and reorganizing Somkhiti under Ottoman administration.
Diplomatic maneuvering between Safavids, Russia, and the Ottomans
Russo–Safavid Treaty (1723)
On 23 September 1723, Safavid Iran ceded Derbent, Baku, Shirvan, Gilan, Mazandaran, and Astarabad to Russia. In exchange, Russia promised (though was unable) to help Tahmasp II regain the throne from the Afghans.
Safavid efforts for peace with the Ottomans
Tahmasp sent envoys to Istanbul, but the Ottomans—angered by the Russo–Iranian treaty—refused negotiations unless Iran ceded territories equivalent to those given to Russia. When this was rejected, the Ottoman advance continued.
Ottoman–Russian Partition Treaty (1724)
After prolonged negotiations mediated by the French ambassador, the Treaty of Istanbul (24 July 1724) partitioned northern and western Iran. Russia acknowledged Ottoman suzerainty over Shirvan, while the Ottomans recognized Russia’s authority over Tahmasp II in its sphere.
Ottoman offensives (1723–1725)
Capture of Kermanshah and Luristan
Baghdad governor Hasan Pasha seized Kermanshah, defeated Ali Mardan at Aleşter, and brought Luristan under Ottoman rule.
Siege of Khoy (1724)
Khoy fell after heavy fighting on 10 April (city) and 12 May (fortress).
Siege of Hamadan (1724)
Ahmed Pasha captured Hamadan on 1 September, followed by Dercezin, Samin, and Ashtaneh.
Siege of Erivan (1724)
After the victory at the Battle of Akçakal, Ottoman forces besieged and captured Erivan: the city on 7 July and the fortress on 28 September.
Siege of Tabriz (1724–1725)
The Ottomans attempted to seize Tabriz twice, with the second attempt in July–August 1725 succeeding after heavy combat.
Ottoman gains in Lori, Ganja, Luristan, Ardabil
Ganja and Lori were annexed, while Ardabil submitted peacefully on the condition that Safi al-Din’s shrine remain untouched.
Hotak diplomacy and renewed conflict (1725–1726)
Ashraf Khan sent an embassy to Istanbul, demanding Ottoman withdrawal, but these demands were rejected. War resumed in 1726.
Ottoman victories (1726)
Ottoman forces won at Arpaçay, Naka, Ordubad, and in Shirvan.
Hotak victory at Anjedan
At Anjedan (20 November), the Ottoman army was defeated when Kurdish cavalry refused to fight another Sunni force.
Peace Negotiations — Treaty of Hamadan (1727)
Exhausted and threatened by both Ottomans and Safavid loyalists, the Hotaks sought peace. Negotiations began on 23 September 1727, and a 12-article treaty was signed on 4 October.
Key terms:
* Hotaks recognized Ottoman gains since 1723 in the Caucasus and western Iran.
* Ottomans recognized Ashraf Khan’s royal title.
* Both sides pledged to protect pilgrimage routes.
* Each side was permitted to station a qadi (judge) for commercial matters in the other’s capital.
* Hotaks surrendered Zanjan, Sultaniyeh, and Abhar.
* A joint border commission was established.
Aftermath
The Ottoman victory was one of the few major successes of the so-called Ottoman “Era of Decline” (1683–1792). However, the Treaty of Hamadan proved short-lived. Nader Shah rose to power, expelled the Hotaks in 1729, restored the Safavids under Tahmasp II, and in 1730 initiated new campaigns against the Ottomans, sparking another prolonged conflict.
Nader Shah's sudden offensive and the Ottoman setbacks contributed directly to unrest in Istanbul, culminating in the Patrona Halil uprising of 1730, which ended the Tulip Era.
